What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned more about Russian literary and art culture and how it was influenced by history. The background reading in history was great for understanding the context for the primary sources and the readings were usually interesting. I learned how to discuss literature and tie it in to the culture we were learning about and experiencing.
I gained a broad overview of Russian Culture and Literature. Exploring authors like Tolstoi to Gogol and Pushkin to Blok it was extremely rewarding as well as reading the texts in Russian as well.
Learned more about russian language and culture
there are many aspects of russian culture, being able to see things from a russian point of view
I gained a little knowledge about Russian art history and St. Petersburg history
A more complete understanding of Russian history and literature.

The course was amazing and interesting. There were few dull moments. It could be improved by spending less time on certain topics so we could cover it all. It also would have been great to discuss more of the historical context in class.
The weakness is the discussion sections kind of being dry but the material was fascinating.
lots of cool insights, but the discussions were long

I think the discussions could be guided more effectively. The reading amounts could also be lowered. You can stay on top of them in New Haven but once you get to Russia its almost impossible to keep up and do well in your language class.

Strengths: The professor is kind and charismatic and understanding, and there is a lot of room to read everything and do everything and learn a TON if it really interests you
Weaknesses: The class is completely nonstructured and the discussion is superficial. The readings are just too much! So not only does nobody do them, but the discussions on them end up being frustratingly superficial, and a lot of the bigger texts don't even get a mention in class. The readings should be diminished, the curriculum more structured, and students given a bigger incentive to do everythingas it is, a few dedicated students do too much and carry the discussions, while mostly everybody does very very little.

Yes, this course is amazing and Professor Firtich is an incredible facilitator for discussions and extremely brilliant when it comes to this literature and art. These works are so important and I was lucky to has Professor Firtich to speak with about them.
Yes especially if you want to take further courses in Russian culture, history, or literature.
its required for the abroad program, so yes

I would definitely recommend the experience in Russia. And maybe if you really love Russian literature, I'd recommend taking this class as well and working as hard as possible to read all the texts and do everythingyou'll come out with an extremely rich knowledge of the subject and learn a ton. However, as a standalone course, no, I would not recommend this class. Not unless it's severely restructured and the readings lessened, with more assignments given throughout the summer to incentivize doing all the reading.
